Transactions on Power Systems","V":16,"I":1,"FP":44,"LP":55,"DOI":"10.1109/59.910780","CC":{"2065350746":["Fuzzy inference [64] and fuzzy-neural models [7], [ 65 ] have also been tried out.\u001bWe are not concerned with the fuzzy modules; fuzzy neural networks [7], [ 65 ] are also outside the scope of this paper."],"2168416146":["Reference [ 52 ] trained a NN with data from a small utility, and found it necessary to smooth their sample data by a manual pre-processing procedure.\u001bReferences [ 52 ], [72] devised heuristics to regularize their data; [18] filtered out the irregularities with a Kalman filter.\u001bThat may mean adding to the NN as many input nodes as the number of classes, and having each class represented by a dummy variable [6], [14], [15], [49], [50], [ 52 ], [57], [66]; or, alternatively, numbering the classes (normally on a binary basis), and feeding these numbers to the NN through a few input nodes, so that a large number of classes may be represented by a weekend days; others reserve them special classes, or devise heuristics to deal with them [ 6 ], [50], [51], [66].\u001bThat may mean adding to the NN as many input nodes as the number of classes, and having each class represented by a dummy variable [ 6 ], [14], [15], [49], [50], [52], [57], [66]; or, alternatively, numbering the classes (normally on a binary basis), and feeding these numbers to the NN through a few input nodes, so that a large number of classes may be represented by a comparatively small number of input nodes [2], [22], [54].\u001bIf the MLP forecasts the profiles, treating them as 24-dimension vectors, the researcher does not have much choice: either he uses data from one past day [2], [17], [51] or from two [ 6 ], [15], [16].\u001bOthers concluded that the only significant weather variable was the temperature [ 6 ], [53], [66].\u001bSome of the papers reported that variations in the number of hidden neurons did not significantly affect forecasting accuracy [ 6 ], [49].\u001bSome papers reported that the utilities would rather evaluate forecasting systems by the absolute errors produced [63], [66], and this suggests that Mean Absolute Errors could be useful (they were reported in [ 6 ], [63], [66])."],"2127301223":["[78], [79], [ 87 ], but they have not been much tested in practice as yet."],"2158442843":["Reference [ 68 ] used three smallsized fully-connected (the exception was in [ 14 ]).\u001bSome authors tried to adapt the Box and Jenkins methodology for fitting ARIMA models, and selected the lags by the analysis of the autocorrelation  Sharp 2001 )."],"1968948510":["The genome of C. elegans encodes a possible ortholog of the Drosophila Dicer protein, K12H4.8, which shares with Dicer a predicted domain structure comprising (from the N terminus to the C terminus) a helicase domain, a PAZ domain ( Cerutti et al. 2000 ), dual RNAse III domains, and a double-stranded RNA-binding domain."],"2152993806":["These small RNA molecules have been named guide RNA, or short interfering RNA (siRNA), and are present in a protein complex that can target homologous mRNA molecules for destruction (Hammond et al. 2000) by cleaving the mRNA molecule within the region spanned by the siRNA molecule ( Elbashir et al. 2001 )."],"2077489356":["In retrospect, it is clear that cosuppression is most likely provoked by dsRNA derived from the multiple transgene copies (Kooter et al. 1999;  Pasquinelli et al. 2000 ).Of interest, the let-7 RNA is 21 nt in length, and it has been hypothesized that the let-7 RNA is produced by post-transcriptional processing of a longer precursor that is predicted to form an extended hairpin structure, which may be a substrate for DCR-1 ( Pasquinelli et al. 2000;  Sharp 2001).Plasterk, unpubl.). (Lane 1) A control reaction with 500-bp dsRNA."],"1518586105":["RNAi is a widespread phenomenon, being present in organisms ranging from fungi to mice (for reviews, see Bass 2000;  Hammond et al. 2001; Tabara et al. 1999; Mourrain et al. 2000;  Wu-Scharf et al. 2000;  Dalmay et al. 2001)."],"2100209874":["One of the natural functions of post-transcriptional gene silencing (PTGS) phenomena appears to be protection against molecular parasites ( Ketting et al. 1999;  Tabara et al. 1999; Mourrain et al. 2000; Dalmay et al. 2001).RNAi and PTGS can clearly function to protect the genome against viruses and transposons (Kasschau and Carrington 1998; Baulcombe 1999;  Ketting et al. 1999;  Tabara et al. 1999; Mourrain et al. 2000; Wu-Scharf et al. 2000; Dalmay et al. 2001)."],"1972268479":["To test the involvement of C. elegans Dicer in RNAi in vivo, we isolated a deletion mutant of dcr-1 ( Jansen et al. 1997 ).The deletion allele pk1351 of K12H4.8 was isolated from a C. elegans deletion library ( Jansen et al. 1997 )."],"1647075334":["RNA interference (RNAi) is a process through which exposure to double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) leads to the silencing of homologous genes, most often post-transcriptionally ( Fire et al. 1998 ).As was observed with Drosophila Dicer, longer dsRNAs are processed more efficiently, which correlates with the observation that long dsRNAs are more effective inducers of RNAi than are short dsRNAs (Fig. 1d;  Fire et al. 1998;  Parrish et al. 2000; Yang et al. 2000)."],"2076628997":["The fact that many plant viruses encode proteins that counteract the PTGS response (Anandalakshmi et al. 1998; Kasschau and Carrington 1998;  Voinnet et al. 1999;  Lucy et al. 2000) indicates the critical nature of this host response."],"1993459319":["In retrospect, it is clear that cosuppression is most likely provoked by dsRNA derived from the multiple transgene copies ( Kooter et al. 1999;  Chuang and Meyerowitz 2000)."],"2120778382":["However, RNAi was first discovered as cosuppression, a response in plants, which leads to simultaneous silencing of exogenous transgenes and homologous endogenous genes (Napoli et al. 1990;  van der Krol et al. 1990 )."],"2062188301":["The fact that many plant viruses encode proteins that counteract the PTGS response (Anandalakshmi et al. 1998; Kasschau and Carrington 1998; Voinnet et al. 1999;  Lucy et al. 2000 ) indicates the critical nature of this host response."],"2091070751":["A characteristic feature of PTGS and RNAi is the presence of low molecular weight RNA derived from either the PTGS-inducing transgene or the exogenous dsRNA, respectively ( Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999;  Hammond et al. 2000; Parrish et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000).These have been observed in plants undergoing cosuppression or virusinduced gene silencing ( Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999 ) and in C. elegans and Drosophila during RNA interference (Hammond et al. 2000; Parrish et al. 2000; Yang et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000).The 22-nt siRNAs that act in RNAi/PTGS have been found in multiple species ( Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999;  Hammond et al. 2000; Parrish et al. 2000; Yang et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000)."],"2169080898":["RNAi and PTGS can clearly function to protect the genome against viruses and transposons (Kasschau and Carrington 1998;  Baulcombe 1999;  Ketting et al. 1999; Tabara et al. 1999; Mourrain et al. 2000; Wu-Scharf et al. 2000; Dalmay et al. 2001)."],"2172286727":["Dicer has been implicated in the production of siRNAs ( Bernstein et al. 2001 ).In Drosophila, biochemical studies have indicated that siRNAs are produced by nucleolytic digestion of the dsRNA silencing trigger (Zamore et al. 2000;  Bernstein et al. 2001 ).We have previously proposed an RNAse III-family nuclease, Dicer, as a candidate for catalyzing the production of siRNAs ( Bernstein et al. 2001 ).DCR-1, like Drosophila Dicer ( Bernstein et al. 2001 ), requires ATPfor efficient cleavage, and ATPhydrolysis further enhances siRNA production (Fig. 1e).We previously hypothesized that ATPhydrolysis by the helicase domain might drive a processive cleavage of dsRNA substrates by Dicer ( Bernstein et al. 2001 ).Drosophila embryos and S2 cell extracts were prepared and all processing reactions were performed as described ( Bernstein et al. 2001 ).Immunoprecipitations were performed as described ( Bernstein et al. 2001 ) except that 100 µL of C. elegans extract was incubated with 10 µL of preimmune or immune serum at 4°C for 1 h.Similar results were obtained in Drosophila ( Bernstein et al. 2001 )."],"1979965542":["The fact that many plant viruses encode proteins that counteract the PTGS response ( Anandalakshmi et al. 1998;  Kasschau and Carrington 1998; Voinnet et al. 1999; Lucy et al. 2000) indicates the critical nature of this host response."],"2123580197":["This RNA, known more generically as a member of a class of small temporal RNAs (stRNAs; Pasquinelli et al. 2000), suppresses the expression of target genes at the translational level by base-pairing to complementary sequences in the 3 UTR ( Slack et al. 2000 ).Regulation by let-7 occurs at the translational level and presumably is mediated by complementary base-pairing between let-7 and the 3-untranslated regions of target genes ( Slack et al. 2000 ).One of the in vivo targets of let-7 is lin-41 ( Slack et al. 2000 ), and the increased expression of this protein in let-7 mutants leads to the burst vulva phenotype.Conversely, hypomorphic alleles of lin-41 have an Egl phenotype (an egg-laying defect), whereas null alleles of lin- 41 are sterile owing to absence of oocytes ( Slack et al. 2000 )."],"2095461860":["A characteristic feature of PTGS and RNAi is the presence of low molecular weight RNA derived from either the PTGS-inducing transgene or the exogenous dsRNA, respectively (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999; Hammond et al. 2000;  Parrish et al. 2000;  Zamore et al. 2000).These have been observed in plants undergoing cosuppression or virusinduced gene silencing (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999) and in C. elegans and Drosophila during RNA interference (Hammond et al. 2000;  Parrish et al. 2000;  Yang et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000).As was observed with Drosophila Dicer, longer dsRNAs are processed more efficiently, which correlates with the observation that long dsRNAs are more effective inducers of RNAi than are short dsRNAs (Fig. 1d; Fire et al. 1998;  Parrish et al. 2000;  Yang et al. 2000).The 22-nt siRNAs that act in RNAi/PTGS have been found in multiple species (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999; Hammond et al. 2000;  Parrish et al. 2000;  Yang et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000)."],"2006100734":["RNAi is a widespread phenomenon, being present in organisms ranging from fungi to mice (for reviews, see  Bass 2000;  Hammond et al. 2001; Plasterk and Ketting 2000; Sharp 2001)."],"2057132428":["The fact that many plant viruses encode proteins that counteract the PTGS response (Anandalakshmi et al. 1998;  Kasschau and Carrington 1998;  Voinnet et al. 1999; Lucy et al. 2000) indicates the critical nature of this host response.RNAi and PTGS can clearly function to protect the genome against viruses and transposons ( Kasschau and Carrington 1998;  Baulcombe 1999; Ketting et al. 1999; Tabara et al. 1999; Mourrain et al. 2000; Wu-Scharf et al. 2000; Dalmay et al. 2001)."],"2146138309":["There may be many other endogenously encoded dsRNAs that are processed by Dicer to produce stRNA molecules, for example, lin-4 ( Olsen and Ambros 1999 )."],"1920303762":["Interestingly, the dcr-1 deletion mutant displays developmental abnormalities, reminiscent of phenotypes caused by loss of function of let-7, a gene encoding a small RNA essential for the proper timing of C. elegans development ( Reinhart et al. 2000 ).Interestingly, this phenotype is also characteristic of loss-of-function mutations in the let-7 gene ( Reinhart et al. 2000 )."],"1916491745":["A characteristic feature of PTGS and RNAi is the presence of low molecular weight RNA derived from either the PTGS-inducing transgene or the exogenous dsRNA, respectively (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999;  Hammond et al. 2000;  Parrish et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000).These small RNA molecules have been named guide RNA, or short interfering RNA (siRNA), and are present in a protein complex that can target homologous mRNA molecules for destruction ( Hammond et al. 2000 ) by cleaving the mRNA molecule within the region spanned by the siRNA molecule (Elbashir et al. 2001).These have been observed in plants undergoing cosuppression or virusinduced gene silencing (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999) and in C. elegans and Drosophila during RNA interference ( Hammond et al. 2000;  Parrish et al. 2000; Yang et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000).Drosophila siRNAs produced in vitro are predominantly 21 bp in length and comigrate with siRNAs that are associated with the RISC enzyme in S2 cells ( Hammond et al. 2000 ).The 22-nt siRNAs that act in RNAi/PTGS have been found in multiple species (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999;  Hammond et al. 2000;  Parrish et al. 2000; Yang et al. 2000; Zamore et al. 2000)."],"2119031123":["For this gene it has been shown that the mismatch between lin-4 and its target is critically required for proper regulation ( Ha et al. 1996 )."],"2030489085":["These have been observed in plants undergoing cosuppression or virusinduced gene silencing (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999) and in C. elegans and Drosophila during RNA interference (Hammond et al. 2000; Parrish et al. 2000;  Yang et al. 2000;  Zamore et al. 2000).As was observed with Drosophila Dicer, longer dsRNAs are processed more efficiently, which correlates with the observation that long dsRNAs are more effective inducers of RNAi than are short dsRNAs (Fig. 1d; Fire et al. 1998; Parrish et al. 2000;  Yang et al. 2000 ).The 22-nt siRNAs that act in RNAi/PTGS have been found in multiple species (Hamilton and Baulcombe 1999; Hammond et al. 2000; Parrish et al. 2000;  Yang et al. 2000;  Zamore et al. 2000)."],"2054109341":["After submission of this work several other labs independently reported on the role of Dicer in RNAi and development: Grishok et al. (2001),  Hutvagner et al. (2001) , and Knight and Bass (2001)."],"2132767295":["In addition, there is some evidence that factors involved in RNAi or PTGS also play a role in proper germ-line development (Bohmert et al. 1998; Jacobsen et al. 1999;  Smardon et al. 2000 )."],"2127497651":["However, RNAi was first discovered as cosuppression, a response in plants, which leads to simultaneous silencing of exogenous transgenes and homologous endogenous genes ( Napoli et al. 1990;  van der Krol et al. 1990)."],"1963759242":["One of the natural functions of post-transcriptional gene silencing (PTGS) phenomena appears to be protection against molecular parasites (Ketting et al. 1999; Tabara et al. 1999; Mourrain et al. 2000;  Dalmay et al. 2001 ).RNAi and PTGS can clearly function to protect the genome against viruses and transposons (Kasschau and Carrington 1998; Baulcombe 1999; Ketting et al. 1999; Tabara et al. 1999; Mourrain et al. 2000; Wu-Scharf et al. 2000;  Dalmay et al. 2001 )."]},"RP":[{"Id":2054109341,"CoC":800},{"Id":2154841861,"CoC":649},{"Id":2117991391,"CoC":616},{"Id":1980269624,"CoC":564},{"Id":2138664009,"CoC":487},{"Id":144423133,"CoC":438},{"Id":1647075334,"CoC":413},{"Id":2014064723,"CoC":409},{"Id":1978976893,"CoC":399},{"Id":2149291473,"CoC":381},{"Id":2151922790,"CoC":378},{"Id":1920303762,"CoC":366},{"Id":2167557255,"CoC":364},{"Id":2168230240,"CoC":338},{"Id":2082213106,"CoC":327},{"Id":2160467221,"CoC":317},{"Id":2136991248,"CoC":316},{"Id":1992941735,"CoC":314},{"Id":2146642335,"CoC":313},{"Id":2152993806,"CoC":313}],"ANF":[{"FN":"René F.","LN":"Ketting","S":1},{"FN":"Sylvia E.J.","LN":"Fischer","S":2},{"FN":"Emily","LN":"Bernstein","S":3},{"FN":"Titia","LN":"Sijen","S":4},{"FN":"Gregory J.","LN":"Hannon","S":5},{"FN":"Ronald H.A.","LN":"Plasterk","S":6}],"BV":"Genes & Development","BT":"a"}

In the horizontal format the database consists of a set of input-sequences.\u001bWe refer the reader to  Agrawal and Srikant (1995)  for additional details on the dataset generation."],"42754116":["The MEDD and MSDD algorithms ( Oates et al., 1997 ) discover patterns in multiple event sequences; they explore the rule space directly instead of the sequence space.\u001b& Agrawal, 1996; Mannila, Toivonen, & Verkamo, 1995;  Oates et al., 1997 )."],"2157086973":["Other domains where sequence mining has been applied include identifying plan failures (Zaki, Lesh, & Ogihara, 1998), finding network alarm patterns ( Hatonen et al., 1996 ), and so on."],"2140909204":["MINE (Zaki, Lesh, & Ogihara, 1998), which has been integrated into two applications in planning: the TRIPS collaborative planning system ( Ferguson & James, 1998 ), and the IMPROVE algorithm for improving large, probabilistic plans (Lesh, Martin, & Allen, 1998)."],"2140894515":["Our new algorithm is based on the fast association mining techniques we presented in  Zaki et al. (1997) ."],"2083140545":["A preliminary version of this paper appeared in  Zaki (1998) ."],"1504344267":["Furthermore, most approaches use very complicated internal data structures which have poor locality ( Parthasarathy, Zaki, & Li, 1998 ), and add additional space and computation overheads.\u001bThese structures typically have very poor locality ( Parthasarathy, Zaki, & Li, 1998 )."],"1597161471":["Sequence discovery can essentially be thought of as association discovery (Agrawal et al., 1996;  Savasere, Omiecinski, & Navathe, 1995 ) over a temporal database."],"2093397547":["Before embarking on the algorithm description, we will briefly review some terminology from lattice theory (see  Davey and Priestley (1990)  for a good introduction)."]},"RP":[{"Id":2158454296,"CoC":724},{"Id":1641039719,"CoC":640},{"Id":2147694185,"CoC":443},{"Id":2068383400,"CoC":352},{"Id":1990800901,"CoC":310},{"Id":2168196587,"CoC":288},{"Id":1676985236,"CoC":246},{"Id":1506285740,"CoC":181},{"Id":1484413656,"CoC":179},{"Id":2166559705,"CoC":167},{"Id":2064853889,"CoC":159},{"Id":2122182354,"CoC":156},{"Id":2156026066,"CoC":154},{"Id":2140190241,"CoC":133},{"Id":1548986531,"CoC":125},{"Id":1549547341,"CoC":117},{"Id":90042445,"CoC":112},{"Id":2154440943,"CoC":103},{"Id":2009418433,"CoC":70},{"Id":2120934516,"CoC":68}],"ANF":[{"FN":"Mohammed Javeed","LN":"Zaki","S":1}],"BV":"Machine Learning","BT":"a"}

semantically, they capture maximal sets of desired behaviors [Dar93,  Let01 ].\u001b[ Let01 ] gives a set of conditions for goal unrealizability; this set is proved complete and provides the basis for a rich, systematic set of agent-driven refinements tactics for generating realizable subgoals and auxiliary agents.\u001bThe principle is to apply derivation rules whose premise match the goal under consideration [Dar93,  Let01 ].\u001bThe presentation will be sketchy for lack of space; the interested reader may refer to [ Let01 ] for a much greater level of details.\u001bIn this goal subgraph, the companion subgoal Maintain[Gate-ClosedWhenSwitchInWrongPosition] was elicited formally by matching a formal refinement pattern to the formalization of the parent goal Avoid[TrainOnSwitchInWrongPosition], found by a WHY question, and to the formalization of the initial goal Avoid[TrainEnteringClosedGate] [Dar96,  Let01 ].\u001bThe formalization of the three subgoals in Figure 3 may be used to prove that together they entail the parent goal Maintain[WCS-DistBetweenTrains] formalized before [ Let01 ].\u001bThe technique for deriving the agent’s monitored and controlled variables is fairly systematic, see [ Let01 ] for details.\u001bAs mentioned before, derivation rules for an operationalization calculus are available [Dar93,  Let01 ].\u001bAcknowledgment. Discussions with Robert Darimont and Emmanuel Letier were a permanent source of inspiration and confrontation of some of the issues raised in this paper; they were in particular instrumental in developing KAOS specifications for various non-trivial systems, including the one outlined here [ Let01 ]."],"2171627300":["A goal under responsibility of a single agent in the software-to-be becomes a requirement whereas a goal under responsibility of a single agent in the environment of the software-to-be becomes an assumption [ Lam98b , Lam98c].\u001bGoals have been recognized to provide the roots for detecting conflicts among requirements and for resolving them eventually [Rob89,  Lam98b ].\u001bPriorities are often used for resolving conflicts among goals [Rob89,  Lam98b ].\u001bThere has been a massive amount of work on linking goals and scenarios together --e.g., [Fic92, Dar93, Pot95, Lei97, Sut98, Ant98, Hau98,  Lam98b , Rol98, Kai00, Ant01].\u001bAt the process level, it may be useful for traceability purpose [Got95] to record which actor owns which goal or some view of it [ Lam98b ].\u001bFormal and heuristic techniques are described in [ Lam98b ] for:  the abductive generation of boundary conditions from goal specifications and domain properties,  the systematic generation of various types of divergence resolution.\u001bThese two goals are formally detected to be divergent using the techniques described in [ Lam98b ].\u001bThe resolution operators from [ Lam98b ] may be used to generate possible resolutions; in this case one should keep the safety goal as it is and weaken the other conflicting goal to remove the divergence:"],"2065095921":["Requirements engineering research has increasingly recognized the leading role played by goals in the RE process [Yue87,  Rob89 , Ber91, Dar91, Myl92, Jar93, Zav97b].\u001bGoals have been recognized to provide the roots for detecting conflicts among requirements and for resolving them eventually [ Rob89 , Lam98b].\u001bPriorities are often used for resolving conflicts among goals [ Rob89 , Lam98b].\u001bOther goal attributes that have been proposed include goal utility and feasibility [ Rob89 ].\u001bThose link types are used to capture alternative goal refinements and potential conflicts, and to prove the correctness of goal refinements (see Section 5). It is generally argued that goal models are built during the early phases of the RE process [Dar93,  Yu97 , Dub98].\u001bGoal types and taxonomies are used to define heuristics for goal acquisition, goal refinement, requirements derivation, and semi-formal consistency/completeness checking [Dar93, Sut93, Ant98, Chu00, Ant01], or to retrieve goal specifications in the context of specification reuse [ Mas97 ].\u001bIn the i* framework [Yu93,  Yu97 ], various types of agent dependency links are defined to model situations where an agent depends on another for a goal to be achieved, a task to be achieved, or a resource to become available.\u001bGoal-based specifications can also be acquired by retrieving structurally and semantically analog specifications in a repository of reusable specification components, and then transposing the specifications found according to the structural and semantic matching revealed by the retrieval process [ Mas97 ]."],"1986186023":["Semi-formal specifications generally declare goals in terms of their type, attribute, and links (see Section 3). Many of them differ significantly with respect to the characteristics of the topologies they generate.\u001bThis includes Waxman models [18], GT-ITM [ 3 ] and Tiers [5].\u001bGT-ITM [ 3 ] and Tiers [5] are primarily concerned with the hierarchical properties of the Internet related to how it is organized as levels of service-providers.\u001bBRITE provides the capability of importing topologies (2) generated by other topology generators (GT-ITM [ 3 ], Inet [9], Tiers [5], BRITE 1.0 [11]) or topological data gathered directly from the Internet (NLANR [12], Skitter [4]).\u001bGeneration models such as Transit-stub [ 3 ] and Tiers [5], are centered around reproducing structural properties of the Internet.\u001bBRITE provides four edge connection mechanisms, borrowed from the popular GT-ITM [ 3 ] topology generator."],"2165084894":["This lack of accuracy is mainly due to the fact that mapping the Internet topology is a very challenging task [ 8 , 17].\u001bAt the Autonomous System (AS) level, available information is richer because it can be obtained or inferred from BGP tables [12, 7]. In contrast, accurate router-level topological information is hard to obtain and until now inferring router-level connectivity has been done by using traceroute or traceroute-like probing mechanisms [ 8 , 4]. Identifying the actual fundamental properties of topologies at the router-level is still an open ..."]},"RP":[{"Id":2105808107,"CoC":214},{"Id":2008620264,"CoC":187},{"Id":1976969221,"CoC":149},{"Id":2118428193,"CoC":95},{"Id":2062939617,"CoC":85},{"Id":2105498167,"CoC":84},{"Id":1532899528,"CoC":79},{"Id":2148662748,"CoC":79},{"Id":2163252320,"CoC":74},{"Id":2167898414,"CoC":74},{"Id":2155659292,"CoC":65},{"Id":3976408,"CoC":64},{"Id":2102056016,"CoC":63},{"Id":2160565743,"CoC":62},{"Id":2097147952,"CoC":61},{"Id":2163059190,"CoC":60},{"Id":2142735084,"CoC":59},{"Id":2123732385,"CoC":58},{"Id":2144553078,"CoC":54},{"Id":2151972741,"CoC":53}],"ANF":[{"FN":"Alberto","LN":"Medina","S":1},{"FN":"Anukool","LN":"Lakhina","S":2},{"FN":"Ibrahim","LN":"Matta","S":3},{"FN":"John W.","LN":"Byers","S":4}],"BV":"MASCOTS 2001, Proceedings Ninth International Symposium on Modeling, Analysis and Simulation of Computer and Telecommunication Systems","BT":"p"}

21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 28, 30].\u001bSince the energy dissipated per cycle with CMOS circuitry scales quadratically to the supply voltage ( ) [ 2 ], DVS can potentially provide a very large net energy savings through frequency and voltage scaling.\u001bIn CMOS technology, used in virtually all microprocessors today, the maximum operating frequency increases (within certain limits) with increased operating voltage, so when the processor is run slower, a reduced operating voltage suffices [ 2 ].\u001bA second important characteristic is that the energy consumed by the processor per clock cycle scales quadratically with the operating voltage ( ) [ 2 ], so even a small change in voltage can have a significant impact on energy consumption."],"2004400944":["Recently, significant propose to adapt the quantization step of each coefficient according to the local noise sensitivity of the eye.\u001bSome modifications of the model proposed in [ 19 ] are introduced here, in order to better fit the behavior of the HVS to the watermarking problem.\u001bSince the first contribution can represent the distance from the edges, whereas the second one the texture, we decided to multiply
